entry.et: Middle English, from Old English æfter; akin to Old High German aftar after, and probably to Old English of of

def.dt: :following in time or place :afterward behind later we arrived shortly after returned 20 years after
:behind in place people lined up one after another
:subsequent to in time or order 20 minutes after 6
:subsequent to and in view of after all our advice

dt.un: used as a function word to indicate the object of a stated or implied action go after gold was asking after you

def.dt: :with the name of or a name derived from that of named after his father
:in the characteristic manner of :in imitation of writing after the manner of Hemingway
:subsequently to the time when we will come after we make plans
:located toward the rear and especially toward the stern of a ship or tail of an aircraft

dt.un: used with a present participle to indicate action completed and especially just completed the poor old man is after dying on me J. M. Synge

def.dt: :in spite of considerations or expectations to the contrary :nevertheless decided to take the train after all didn't rain after all
:in view of all circumstances literature which is after all only a special department of reading W. W. Watt
:engaged in or operating after a legal or conventional closing time after–hours drinking an after–hours club
:a party for invited guests that follows a main party or event
:remaining after payment of taxes and especially of income tax an after–tax profit
